docs.lead_paragraph: 75 years ago, Marguerite Perey unearthed an element on the periodic table while working as a technician in Marie Curie’s lab. Her achievement came at a great cost.

headline.main: My Great-Great-Aunt Discovered Francium. And It Killed Her.

docs.abstract: Veronique Greenwood article recounts experience of her great-great-aunt Marguerite Perey, who worked under Marie Curie, and came to discover element francium at great cost to her health because of radiation poisoning; says story is a reminder that society should celebrate scientists for their courage and tenacity required to discover anything at all.
docs.snippet: 75 years ago, Marguerite Perey unearthed an element on the periodic table while working as a technician in Marie Curie’s lab. Her achievement came at a great cost.

docs.lead_paragraph: A ProPublica analysis found that many health insurance plans offered in the federal marketplace are changing their benefits heading into 2015.

headline.main: Big Changes in Fine Print of Some 2015 Health Plans
headline.print_headline: Hidden in the Fine Print, Big Changes in Some ’15 Health Plans

docs.abstract: ProPublica analysis of 2014 and 2015 health care plans being offered on federal government's health insurance exchange in 34 states shows that many plans have made changes that could markedly affect how much consumers pay; people seeking health care on exchange face complex battery of choices as they pick plans for 2015.
docs.snippet: A ProPublica analysis found that many health insurance plans offered in the federal marketplace are changing their benefits heading into 2015.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By CHARLES ORNSTEIN, RYANN GROCHOWSKI JONES and LENA GROEGER

docs.lead_paragraph: The flu vaccine may not be very effective this winter, according to U.S. health officials who worry this may lead to more serious illnesses and deaths.

headline.main: Flu Vaccine May Be Less Effective This Winter
headline.print_headline: Flu Vaccine May Be Less Effective This Winter

docs.snippet: The flu vaccine may not be very effective this winter, according to U.S. health officials who worry this may lead to more serious illnesses and deaths.

docs.lead_paragraph: The data for 2013 did not show, however, whether cost controls in the Affordable Care Act or the aftereffects of the recession were responsible for the slowdown.
docs.abstract: Obama administration reports health care spending in United States totaled $2.9 trillion in 2013, up 3.6 percent from 2012; is lowest rate of increase since government started tracking it in 1960.
docs.snippet: The data for 2013 did not show, however, whether cost controls in the Affordable Care Act or the aftereffects of the recession were responsible for the slowdown.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health care spending grew by the slowest rate in more than a half-century last year, government analysts said Wednesday. But a speed-up is coming as the economy gets traction and the new health care law covers more people.

headline.main: Growth for US Health Tab May Have Hit Bottom
headline.print_headline: Growth for US Health Tab May Have Hit Bottom

docs.snippet: U.S. health care spending grew by the slowest rate in more than a half-century last year, government analysts said Wednesday. But a speed-up is coming as the economy gets traction and the new health care law covers more people.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York Times documentary and article look at mine workers in Myanmar struggling with poverty and drug addiction even as the country’s jade industry is booming because of demand from China.

headline.seo: Video Feature: Jade’s Journey Marked by Drugs and Death
headline.main: Searching for Burmese Jade, and Finding Misery
headline.print_headline: Searching for Burmese Jade, and Finding Misery

docs.abstract: Much of wealth generated by Myanmar's booming jade industry is in control of elite members of military, rebel leaders and Chinese financiers who help them smuggle billions of dollars' worth of the gem into China; corrupt trade has robbed government of billions in tax revenues, fed violent ethnic conflict and mired members of Kachin minority, who work the mines, in poverty, heroin addiction and HIV infection.
docs.snippet: A New York Times documentary and article look at mine workers in Myanmar struggling with poverty and drug addiction even as the country’s jade industry is booming because of demand from China.

byline.contributor: Jonah M. Kessel contributed reporting. Chen Jiehao and Becky Davis contributed research from Beijing.
